text: This is a meteor coming towards you. This is going to radically transform society. And I think if people don't explore AI properly, it will leave them behind. I'd start with the thing your product does. "What's the core premise behind it? Why do people use it? What problem does it solve for them?" That kind of thing. So, go back to basics. And then ask, "Can AI do that?"
speaker: Paul Adams
context: Lenny asks Paul about his broader insights on AI and how it will integrate into product strategy. Paul explains his belief that AI represents a massive technology shift comparable to or bigger than mobile and the internet. He advocates for a methodical approach to evaluating AI's impact on your product: first understand your core value proposition and user problems, then assess whether AI can solve those same problems.
text_ko: 이건 당신 쪽으로 날아오는 운석이에요. 사회를 근본적으로 바꿔 놓을 거예요. 그리고 사람들이 인공지능(AI)을 제대로 들여다보지 않으면 뒤처질 거라고 생각해요. 저는 우선 제품(product)이 하는 일부터 살펴볼 것 같아요. "그 제품의 핵심 전제(core premise)는 뭔가요? 사람들이 왜 쓰죠? 어떤 문제를 해결해 주나요?" 이런 식으로요. 기본으로 돌아가서, 그리고 나서 "인공지능(AI)이 그걸 할 수 있을까요?"라고 물어보세요.
text_zh: 这就像一颗流星朝你砸过来一样。这会彻底改变整个社会。我觉得如果大家不好好研究AI的话，肯定会被甩在后面。我建议先从你们产品本身入手。"它的核心逻辑是什么？用户为什么要用它？它帮他们解决了什么痛点？"就是这些基本问题。所以，回到原点去思考。然后再问自己，"AI能做这件事吗？"
text_es: Esto es como un meteorito que viene hacia ti. Va a transformar la sociedad de manera radical. Y creo que si la gente no explora bien la IA, se va a quedar atrás. Yo empezaría con lo que hace tu producto. "¿Cuál es la idea central? ¿Por qué lo usa la gente? ¿Qué problema les resuelve?" Ese tipo de cosas. O sea, volver a lo básico. Y después preguntarte: "¿Puede la IA hacer eso?"

text: You can get sidetracked by the technology, for sure. And I do. I just mentioned, hey, going out for dinner and taking a photo of my food. You can get sidetracked by the tech and some of it's really cool. I wouldn't start there. I'd start with the thing your product does. What's the core premise behind it? Why do people use it? What problem does it solve for them? That kind of thing.
speaker: Paul Adams
context: Lenny asks Paul to elaborate on how to think strategically about whether your product is in the path of AI disruption. Paul warns against getting distracted by flashy AI capabilities and instead recommends starting with fundamental product questions. He emphasizes understanding your product's core value proposition before determining how AI might impact it.
text_ko: 물론 기술(technology)에 신경이 쓰여 곁길로 새는 경우가 있어요. 저도 그래요 — 아까 말한 것처럼 저녁 먹으러 가서 음식 사진 찍는 것처럼요. 기술이 멋진 건 맞지만 거기서 시작하진 않아요. 저는 제품(product)이 실제로 뭘 하는지부터 시작해요. 그 밑에 있는 핵심 전제(core premise)는 뭔가요? 사람들이 왜 쓰나요? 어떤 문제를 해결해 주나요? 그런 것들이요.
text_zh: 技术确实容易让人分心，我也会这样。就像我刚说的，出去吃饭还要给菜拍照。你很容易被那些酷炫的技术带跑偏，有些确实挺有意思的。但我不会从这里入手。我会从你的产品本身做什么开始。它的核心价值主张(core premise)是什么？用户为什么要用它？它帮他们解决了什么问题？就是这些东西。
text_es: Claro que te puedes distraer con la tecnología, sin duda. Y a mí me pasa. Como te decía, salir a cenar y tomarle foto a la comida. Te puedes ir por las ramas con la tecnología y algunas cosas están padrísimas. Pero yo no empezaría por ahí. Yo empezaría con lo que hace tu producto en realidad. ¿Cuál es la premisa central? ¿Por qué la gente lo usa? ¿Qué problema les resuelve? Ese tipo de cosas.

text: We literally ripped up our strategy almost entirely, and started again, from first principles and said, "Okay, why do people use Intercom?" Intercom is a customer support product. And then, very soon after that, Sam Altman, who's the founder and head of OpenAI, said, "Hey, one of the first industries that's going to be disrupted is customer service." We're like, "Yep."
speaker: Paul Adams
context: Lenny asks for an example of how AI can fully replace existing product functionality. Paul describes how Intercom completely changed their strategy after ChatGPT launched on November 29th. When OpenAI's Sam Altman identified customer service as one of the first industries AI would disrupt, Intercom realized they needed to pivot their entire approach and build AI-first solutions.
text_ko: 우리는 전략을 거의 완전히 갈아엎고 처음부터 다시 시작했어요. 기본 원칙(first principles)부터 다시 되짚어 보면서 “사람들이 왜 Intercom을 쓰는 거지?”라고 물었죠. Intercom은 고객 지원(customer support) 제품이에요. 그리고 얼마 지나지 않아 OpenAI의 창업자 겸 대표인 샘 올트먼이 “가장 먼저 영향을 받게 될 산업 중 하나가 고객 서비스(customer service)다”라고 했어요. 우리는 “그렇죠”라고 했어요.
text_zh: 我们基本上把原来的战略全部推倒重来，从最基本的问题开始思考："用户为什么要用Intercom？"Intercom本质上就是个客服产品。然后没过多久，OpenAI的创始人兼负责人Sam Altman就说："客服行业肯定是首批被AI颠覆的行业之一。"我们当时就想："没错，就是这样。"
text_es: Literalmente tiramos nuestra estrategia casi por completo a la basura y empezamos de cero, desde los principios básicos, y dijimos: "A ver, ¿por qué la gente usa Intercom?" Intercom es un producto de atención al cliente. Y luego, muy poco después, Sam Altman, que es el fundador y director de OpenAI, dijo: "Oye, una de las primeras industrias que va a ser revolucionada es el servicio al cliente." Y nosotros: "Exacto."

text: The advice I have for people, and the advice I have for myself, I'm in that too, I wake up every day to too many emails, and Slack chats, and people knocking on my door, and my desk, and all things. So, this is a challenge for me too. You just have to take the time. There's just no other way for me. And that to me doesn't mean... It's about priorities.
speaker: Paul Adams
context: Lenny asks what advice Paul would give to people who want to go deeper into AI but don't have time due to their existing workload. Paul acknowledges he faces the same challenge with emails and meetings, but emphasizes that learning about AI must become a priority. He stresses that staying current with AI isn't optional - it requires dedicated time and prioritization.
text_ko: 사람들에게 해주는 조언이자 제 자신에게도 하는 말인데요, 저도 그래요. 매일 너무 많은 이메일과 슬랙 메시지, 사람들이 문을 두드리거나 제 책상으로 불쑥 찾아오는 등으로 하루가 시작돼요. 저한테도 큰 도전이에요. 그래서 시간을 따로 내야 해요. 저한텐 다른 방법이 없더라고요. 그리고 그게 의미하는 건… 결국 우선순위의 문제예요.
text_zh: 我给别人的建议，也是给自己的建议，我也是这样的，每天一醒来就是一堆邮件，Slack消息，还有人敲门找我，桌子上也是乱七八糟的，什么都有。所以我也面临这个挑战。你就得挤时间出来，对我来说没别的办法。这不是说... 关键还是看你怎么排优先级。
text_es: El consejo que les doy a otros, y que me doy a mí mismo porque yo también estoy en la misma, es que me levanto cada día con demasiados emails, chats de Slack, gente tocando mi puerta, cosas en mi escritorio, de todo. O sea, para mí también es un reto. Simplemente tienes que darte el tiempo. Para mí no hay de otra. Y eso no significa... Se trata de prioridades.

text: I think customer support is definitely... Like I said, number one, customer support. So you're like, "Okay, I guess we should adapt." Adapt or die is our mantra. Adapt or die. I think that there are other industries where they're on the same journey, it's just not as obvious.
speaker: Paul Adams
context: Lenny asks what helps people gain conviction about AI's importance, noting that customer support seems like a clear opportunity for AI integration. Paul confirms that customer support was identified as the top industry for AI disruption, making their decision clearer. He introduces Intercom's core philosophy of "adapt or die" while acknowledging that other industries face similar AI transformation challenges, though the path may be less obvious.
text_ko: 저는 고객 지원이 확실히... 아까 말했듯이, 가장 중요한 건 고객 지원이에요. 그래서 사람들이 “그럼 우리도 적응해야겠다”라고 생각하죠. '적응하라 아니면 도태된다(Adapt or die)'가 저희 신조예요. 다른 업종들도 같은 길을 가고 있다고 생각하는데, 그게 그렇게 뚜렷하게 보이진 않을 뿐이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得客户服务绝对是...就像我刚说的，排第一位的就是客户服务。所以你就会想，"好吧，看来我们得适应变化了。"适应或淘汰(adapt or die)就是我们的座右铭。要么适应，要么被淘汰。我觉得其他行业其实也在走同样的路，只是没有那么明显而已。
text_es: Creo que el soporte al cliente es definitivamente... Como te dije, número uno, soporte al cliente. Entonces piensas, "Bueno, supongo que tenemos que adaptarnos." Adaptarse o morir es nuestro lema. Adaptarse o morir. Creo que hay otras industrias que están en el mismo camino, simplemente no es tan obvio.

text: Number one thing I would say is keep it simple. Keep it simple. It's so tempting to... With us, for example, a lot of SaaS products have add-ons, where you're like, "Hey, we built X and that's 10 bucks." Or 100,000, depends on what product you're selling. "We built X and that's the price of X. Hey, we've just built Y. Y is awesome and it's a new thing you can do, and it unlocks all these new capabilities."
speaker: Paul Adams
context: Lenny asks for pricing wisdom based on Paul's experience with Intercom's complex pricing challenges. Paul emphasizes that pricing is deceptively difficult, comparing it to onboarding as one of the hardest design problems. He explains how companies often start simple but gradually add complexity through add-ons and tiers, making customer bills incomprehensible. His key lesson is to resist the temptation to add multiple pricing models.
text_ko: 제일 먼저 드리고 싶은 말은 단순하게 하라는 거예요. 정말 단순하게 유지하세요. 복잡하게 확장하고 싶어지는 유혹이 크거든요. 예를 들어 우리 같은 경우 많은 SaaS 제품(SaaS products)은 애드온(add-ons)이 있어서 “우리가 X를 만들었고 그게 X의 가격이에요—10달러일 수도 있고 100,000일 수도 있어요(판매하는 제품에 따라 달라요).” 그런 다음에 “방금 Y를 만들었어요. Y는 멋지고 새로운 기능이라서 이걸로 여러 새로운 가능성이 열려요”라고 계속 추가하는 식이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得最重要的一点就是保持简单。一定要保持简单。真的特别容易陷入这样的陷阱...比如说我们这种情况，很多SaaS产品都有附加功能，你会说："嘿，我们开发了X功能，卖10块钱。"或者10万块，这得看你卖的是什么产品了。"我们开发了X功能，X功能就是这个价格。嘿，我们刚开发了Y功能。Y功能超棒的，是个全新的东西，能解锁各种新能力。"
text_es: Lo principal que te diría es que lo mantengas sencillo. Que lo mantengas sencillo. Es súper tentador... Con nosotros, por ejemplo, muchos productos SaaS tienen complementos (add-ons), donde dices, "Oye, creamos X y eso cuesta 10 dólares." O 100,000, depende del producto que vendas. "Creamos X y ese es el precio de X. Oye, acabamos de crear Y. Y está padrísimo y es algo nuevo que puedes hacer, y te abre un montón de nuevas posibilidades."
